captions.text: [CAR ENGINES]
So it happened like this.

Bentley contacted me and said
they'd lend me, very kindly, a

Continental GT Speed, the new
620-horsepower, very fast

version of the new
Continental.

I said, yes, I'm sure
we can do something
interesting with that.

Anyhow, last Friday I drove the
car having spent the day

in the 599, and I really was
surprised at how good it was
on the road.

The amount of performance you
could put onto the road

service in any conditions,
it was just, as I said,
impressive.

Next day I got up, and there
happened to be a new Audi S4
on the driveway as well.

We get quite a few cars coming
through, as you can imagine,
because cars are our job.

And I got in the Audi and
I drove down the road.

And I suddenly thought, good
lord, there are quite obvious

similarities between the way
these cars drive, the way they

put their performance onto the
road, the way the cabins feel,
some of the control ways.
This was odd.

But of course, it isn't
odd, is it?

Because they're both owned
by Volkswagen.

So what I want to do here is
investigate the new GT Speed

and tell you what it's like
to drive because it's

significance and it needs
some air time.

But I also want to bring this
Audi in and try and explore

the nature of driving
characteristics and how these

increasingly large conglomerates
are owning many

different brands but perhaps
struggling to give those
brands real distinct identities
within the larger groups.

I mean, should an Audi S4 have
anything in common with a

Bentley that costs
180,000 pounds?

I mean a bit of me says, no,
it's absolutely wrong.

Then another bit of me says,
hang on a minute, the S4 is

possibly the best
car Audi makes.

So isn't that a real complement
that the Bentley

can replicate some of those
utterly seamless, absolutely

brilliant on-road
characteristics.
Anyhow, here we go.

A strange investigation,
but I hope a fun one.

It seems to be increasingly the
case that engineers these

days can hide the mass of a
vehicle very, very cleverly.
It's magic, isn't it?
This car weights 2.3 tons.

That's a vast amount
of weight.

And yet because the steering is
so accurate and the chassis

can put so much power
onto the road, it
doesn't feel that heavy.

It must have some very, very
clever spring and damper rates

as well because the ride
is very compliant.
I know the mass helps that.

But it's not so lazy in
direction changes as I thought
it would be.
It's quite agile.

You can make it go left right,
left right, left right very

quickly and it follows
the line.

You don't feel it getting
away from you.
The motor, wow.

The torque, 590 foot pounds
from well under 2000 RPM.

You don't even have to think
about overtaking stuff.

You just squeeze the throttle
and it goes.

It feels 620-horsepower
strong as well.
Quite a bit of extra money.

But you get 50 horsepower over
the standard car and over 70

foot pounds of torque
as well more.

Does it feel like it has
the performance of a
180,000 pound Super GT?
Abso-bloomin-lutely!

You can also nudge it
into sport mode.

The exhaust starts to
make more noise.

And then it kind of erupts
down the road.
It's fast.

It doesn't have a double
clutch gear box.

Eight speeds at half-automatic,
which works
very, very well.

We're really learning to like
and love this transmission.

But I think what's most
impressive about this car is

the amount of composure and
comfort it retains at high

speed over and above other
cars in the class.

A Ferrari FF, a car which I'm
not supposed to have driven,

is actually quite a bit busier
at speed than this thing.

So dynamically, this is
better than expected.

And I was very impressed that
night when I drove it quickly
on some damp roads.

There's some winter
tires there.

It seems to be the least
affected car by going on
winter tires that I've driven.

There are very few cars that
have managed to take turbo

charging and turn it into
something that actually adds
character to a package.
Think of a few.

Some of the early Porche
turbos, GT 2's,
definitely the F-40.

The F-40 is a more characterful
car because it's
turbo-charged.

But this modern template for
quite heavily turbo-charged,

smaller capacity engines and
self-shifting gear boxes, I

think, is becoming
a bit repetitive.

Sadly, like anything, these
formulas, once they are deemed

to work well, just get copied
and copied and copied.

So we end up in a situation
where I think the Bentley

slightly comes undone
because the power
train feels quite generic.
OK, it's not ordinary.
A W12 doesn't sound ordinary.

But there are some sort of
synthesized voices going on.

Sometimes the car-- well the
motor and the induction noise
is slightly odd.

You put it into sport and the
exhaust makes a slightly self

conscious, sort of, woofly,
almost breaking windy sound.

It's not really thoroughbred
noise.

It doesn't harp back to
anything in the past.

And it doesn't really excite
me when I'm in the car.

OK, I'm not denying it's
very, very effective.

But I don't think you get out of
it with your spine tingling
in any way.

It really is such a shame that
the Continental GT is saddled

with a slightly footballer-ish
image because there really

isn't anything else
quite like it.

This speed model is not far
off 911 turbo-quick in a
straight line.

But it's quieter and more
comfortable than
many an exec saloon.
And so it should be.

The double-glazed side windows
mean the doors weigh about as
much as the Audi.
That's the whole Audi.

The quality in here
is just sublime.

The knurled vent controllers,
the gleaming chrome

everything, and the soft, waxy
leather that smells expensive.

On one level, I think the Conty
GT struggles to assert

itself over the more expensive
BMWs and Mercs because it's

lacking a distinctive
character.

But spend five minutes
in the cabin,
and you'll be convinced.

It's miles more special than
anything from a volume
manufacturer.

Of course, after the Bentley,
the S4 feels about as

luxurious as Wright's Coal Tar
Soap, but I like it that way.

It continues the understatement
theme from the
ordinary exterior.

People just don't expect
to see you smoke them.

And for that reason, I'd quite
like to delete the quad tail

pipes that are the only
real giveaway.

I've banged on about this
particular car before because

I think it's the kind
of unsung hero of
fast sporting Audis.

When they try and do RS cars,
sometimes they go a bit too

far I think and get it
wrong, but the S4 is
a real sweet spot.

Loads of torque, very
fast on kind of
British wet, greasy roads.
Quick and fun as well.
Frugal.

I mean, it's a great balance of
everything you'd want in a

smaller state car
and so discreet.

This silver one, you can't even
see the trinkety silver

wing mirrors over the
normal body color.
It just looks so ordinary.

I think the wheels are actually
smaller than on a
standard S-line model.
Anyhow.

I want to discuss the increased
homogenization of

cars under one particular
group, don't I?

And in this case it's
the VW group.

I'm not singling them out
because I want to get at them.

I just think it's a very
interesting exercise.

I'm now sitting in a
40-something thousand pound
smaller state car.

It couldn't be further
removed from the old
Benters back there.

I have a steering wheel which
feels very similar in diameter
in my hands.

I've got two clock
faces there.

I've got a computer screen
around here.
I've got a lever right here.

And I've got a hand brake on
or off switch just here.

Does that remind you
of anything?
To me it does.

If I were to drive this
blindfolded, the controls are

exactly where they are
in the Bentley.

OK, the heated seats are down
here in the Bentley and
they're up here on the Audi.
But it keeps on coming out.
It just feels quite same-y.

Do we have to have everything
so similar?

What about the way
the car performs?

Well, throttle weight
is a little bit
lighter on this car.
That reads about right.

But the way the performance
comes at me, the way that the

car will hold on to a gear to
use the torque from this

rather clever supercharged V6,
or just kick down a cog

imperceptibly and then just
go with very little effort

whatsoever, that is definitely
reminiscent of the Bentley.

If you were to define power
characteristics in several

cars and maybe come up with
five different definitions

from top end screamy VTEC-y
style 4 cylinders and maybe

torque-y motors, this and the
Bentley would definitely sit
in the same category.
It feels quite similar.

Does this mean that people
from Audi drive Bentleys,

people from Bentley drive Audis,
before they are all
released to the marketplace?

Well, we know for a
fact that they do.

Is that information exchange
a positive thing?

Or does it detract from the
character of these cars?

That to me is a quite
interesting point.

You might find it very dull,
which I apologize.

I think the S4, particularly in
silver, as I said, might be
the ultimate Q-car.
It's so discreet.

It looks so ordinary
from the outside.

But when you want to go
quite quick, it's got
plenty going for it.
Motor sounds good.
Rev sounds sweetly.
It's got loads of torque.

The one thing this car's got
over the Bentley is that the

double clutch gear box in this
car works especially well with
this supercharged engine.
So it's quick, quick, quick.

And the gear shifts are
absolutely incisive.

Bang, you're into
the next gear.

No, a clever thing,
a clever thing.

So, am I actually paying the
Bentley a massive complement

by saying it shares some driving
characteristics with

an Audi that's worth a little
bit more than the combined

total of the optional extras
fitted to that GT speed?
Perhaps I am.

So this is where I stand
on the subject.

On the one hand, I really
appreciate the fact that cars

now drive in such a
sophisticated manner.

That power trains are so easy
and usable because of these

clever new gear boxes and
because there are large groups

like VW that can allow their
technologies and learnings to

cross-pollinate between
different brands.
I think that's a great idea.

However, I think we have to mark
a word of caution here.

I do think it makes some cars
struggle for character.

And does it matter that
an Audi S4 has not
got that much character?
I'm not sure it does.

It's a bit more of an
appliance, isn't it?

To most people, it's a very
expensive, very fast car.
I'll give you that.

But actually it's an A4 with
a really potent engine.

And it's designed to just cross
country quickly and kind

of integrate into someone's
life imperceptibly.

So it doesn't matter that it's
not bristling with character.

The Bentley, that's a bit more
of a problem, isn't it?

Because even though that GT
Speed does so many things so

well, even though I love
spending time in it, oddly it

doesn't have a distinct
character to me.

Ferrari FF has a distinct
character.

But the Bentley, to me, it
doesn't necessarily leap out
at me as being a Bentley.
It could be many things.
It could be a large Porche.
It could be a large Audi.

I know it's beautifully
finished.

But it doesn't strike me at
being obviously a Bentley.

And I think that is quite
a dangerous thing.

The most difficult aspect of
defining multiple brands whose

market space sometimes overlaps
with each other and

which sometimes share many
components is giving them a
distinct character.

That isn't a problem between
these two cars because they're

priced so far apart
from each other.

Much like that famous story of
Aston Martin employee decades

ago deflecting accusations that
using Ford switch gear
would upset owners.

He simply replied that it was
doubtful any Aston owners had

actually sat in a modern Ford,
so they would never know.

Well, the Speed and the Audi
occupy different territories.

At times they feel spookily cut
from the same cloth, but

mostly they just feel like
very, very good cars.

title: Bentley Continental GT Speed and Audi S4: Exploring VW Group DNA - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text: And the golf. They are all the same.﻿

comments.text:
I always like Chris's videos, but I do have to disagree with him on a 
couple of points. Firstly, I think the Bentley is quite distinctive and has 
a lot of character, and I doubt you'd mistake it for a car from any other 
marque. For me, the Bentley is a lovely car and the Audi S4 is ugly. I find 
all Audi's to be so. I strongly dislike their styling. Secondly, I think 
the ultimate Q-ship is probably the Mercedes E63 AMG Estate wagon, rather 
than the S4. In my opinion,it looks better, has better acceleration and 
handling, and has a great exhaust note as well.﻿

comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text:
[cont] or for that matter a current Bently) and much of what he has to say 
is a bit subjective and personal, but that's what I watch it for. I can 
read the claimed power figure and weight figure and have a rough idea what 
the car will do, but I can only guess what it feels like and how well 
sorted the dynamics are, and I'm quite interested in Chris's impressions 
and comments here, because he can communicate, and he can drive. And it 
makes pleasant viewing, more fun than the news, but not [cont]
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text:
Damn! Your personal replys are blocked. Oh well, public then. First thing, 
I don't want to argue, I think we're on pretty much the same side. I could 
perhaps have read your original post a little more carefully, including who 
and what you replied to. I blame the overall standard of these comment 
debates, which isn't high. The points I was making, as far as I remember, 
were that Chris gets to fang around in stuff I hardly ever see, (I've never 
seen a Pagani or a Bugatti in the flesh, [cont]
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text: LOL - ah, sorry. As you were.
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text:
77.8% of people reading can't distinguish between crashing and being 
crashed into? You don't need to, and most people would say they were 
crashed into. Where I live, the police and insurance companies would come 
to a conclusion of who was at fault, and whoever was at fault crashed into 
someone/something else, and the other party was crashed into. Where I live 
we don't antagonise and call the police biased, nor do the insurance 
companies cheat us. Yes it might happen, but it is very rarely.
comments.author: josef959

comments.text:
I was agreeing with you. My statements were subjective, purposefully, much 
like yours were. I didn't apply hard numbers to Mr Harris' subjective and 
personal opinions, I applied them to Mr Halls. Where he stated that 5.1 
seconds was "atrocious" compared to the Bentley's 4 seconds. When in 
reality, both are impressive for a car. It is the automotive equivalent of 
saying 100m sprint of 10 seconds is atrocious compared to Usain Bolt's 9.58 
seconds.
comments.author: josef959

comments.text:
In case this is getting a bit too obscure, you apply hard numbers to Mr 
Harris's subjective and personal opinions about a car that many of us will 
never see, and use a line of argument that could be turned or twisted 
against any mass produced consumer product, and when gently ridiculed on 
that, you tell me I'm being subjective? I'm pointing out your line and 
method of argument could easily be used in ways you don't like, against 
things you do.
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text:
'Subjective?' 34.7% of observers won't care. 77.8% of people reading this 
can hardly distinguish between crashing and being crashed into, after being 
pummelled with numbers and opinions their whole lives. Mathematics is a 
good and valuable tool set, for understanding and dealing with the world. 
Statistics is (often) the subset of that toolkit involved with rhetoric, 
advertising, manipulation and ridicule, most used by shysters and snake oil 
salesmen.
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text:
All those questions are very subjective, the point of my statements is to 
highlight that just because something isn't the "fastest" or the "best" 
doesn't mean that it isn't more than good enough for anybody. Also safer 
could mean "crash better" but it also mean "be crashed into better."
comments.author: josef959

comments.text:
LOL - a good point, but be careful, that's a slippery slope. Is your new 
Toyota really that much better than a 1962 Beetle? Do you really need to go 
that fast? So it'd crash better - do you plan to crash it? Anything less 
... agricultural than a Morris Marina or an old Beetle, is a luxury... 
Perhaps, any petrol driven privately owned device is an unacceptable 
luxury...
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text:
I would say that acceleration is the result of the torque those cars have. 
Again, 1.5ms^-2 may be a pretty big difference, but does it matter? Yes, 
you're right it can be. But that doesn't make my question any less 
relevant.
comments.author: josef959

comments.text:
I think 1.5ms^-2 acceleration difference is pretty big, especially 
considering these cars are very heavy, and hence requires much more torque. 
Also, you can use the same argument for almost anything, like the max 
speed, horsepower, rev, etc. Really, who would need more than 100HP in a 
car if you buy a car based on "how many times in your life..."
comments.author: John Kang

comments.text:
You average 6.94 metres/second/second vs. 5.45 metres/second/second. 
Consider that probably 95% of the cars on the road max out at an average 
acceleration rate of 3 metres/second/second. How many times in your life 
would accelerating 2.33 times faster than most other cars be necessary than 
accelerating 1.82 times faster than most other cars? Also, how many times 
in your life have you ever had a situation where you did need to accelerate 
flat out?
comments.author: josef959

comments.text:
If you look at it that way, yes. However, in terms of actual acceleration, 
the extra second translates to much lower acceleration.
comments.author: John Kang

comments.author: Toyota4Life

comments.text:
The question is do you care. If your supercar has a certain button or dash 
layout that is already efficient, elegant, and well-designed, why would you 
care if it has a similar layout to another car? Would you demand that it be 
changed just so you can call your car unique? I mean, many cars I know have 
four wheels, 2 headlights in the front, steering wheels that are made out 
of leather. By the above logic, are all of these cars too similar to each 
other then?
comments.author: 133j0hn

comments.text:
the golf has the best platform of any car in the class by a really far

mqb platform. if you talk about passion I must assume that you have no idea 
what you are talking about. every car enthusiast is happy for good cars no 
matter who build it and as far as 'money machine' goes. just pay twice the 
price if you like. by a hand build car next time.

comments.author: 133j0hn

comments.text:
I think this "cross-pollination" issue is only noticeable to people like 
Chris Harris, who get to drive upwards of a few hundred different cars in 
their lifetimes. The average joe wouldn't even get to drive that many 
high-end vehicles from the same auto group, much less notice or care that 
there are a few buttons that are positioned in the same area.

comments.text:
Nice video. Personally, I love that the VW/Audi Group make such good cars, 
and that there is something of a family resemblance between them. The 
Ford/Aston Martin point is definitely relevant here, but even if a Bentley 
owner were to, say, buy an Audi for their son or daughter or whatever, that 
family resemblance I think simply adds to the value of the Audi, without 
detracting from the Bentley. Personally, I love them all. The RS5 is my 
current "budget" dream car.
comments.author: Michael "Blue" Erdmier

comments.text: Chris Harris is such a good car journalist and he seems like such a nice guy
comments.author: Vincent Cardella

comments.text:
What's the point in common? Both cars belong to different segments and 
price ranges! If I had the money I would definetely buy a Bentley!
comments.author: Fernando Maldonado

comments.text: fag
comments.author: Roy Critchfield

comments.text: *these. And: no. :P
comments.author: Esteban Franchina

comments.text:
The goal of each car manufacturer is a money machine. That is the purpose 
of business. And with well-considered purchases, VW has not only a lot of 
foreign know-how purchased, but also traditional brands saved from ruin, 
and that jobs in these countries. And Info. All the VW daughters - with the 
exception of Skoda - can pretty much do whatever they want.
comments.author: Lightfromsirius

comments.text:
Ok, we'd like to think that it's true what you say. I would now ask the 
question. Until this year, when VW went into the WRC, they also had a 
vehicle in the ERC, based on the Polo. Did that many people have heard or 
seen? No! And why? Because Skoda dominates on the same basis, the Polo, the 
ERC. With ease. And the VW Polo never play a role. Most of whom came to the 
finish when Skoda was already on his way home. How can that be if it's true 
what you say?
comments.author: Lightfromsirius

comments.text:
I never liked the look of supercars ;P I like the 'square' look of german 
executive cars.
comments.author: Frank Sandqvist

comments.text:
Interesting episode, Chris. Almost all of VW group's cars are extremely 
similar, but I think economically it kind of has to be that way...a case in 
point being British Leyland. They DIDN'T share know-how across the brands, 
or use the same engines and look what happened to them...
comments.author: SirLoinOfsteak85

especially a b8 a4 2.0t with apr k04 upgrade and stock exhaust. dream right

comments.text:
Very nice review. And no Dunkin. So having taken this extrapolation,the 
question is ..which Skoda ..the Bentley owner may have sat in an Audi (?) 
you can be sure,they have never sat in a Skoda. And if you find a gem in 
the bargain bucket, the Bentley owner will be OK with it, but the Audi 
owner? Red faced of Woking? Has VW group started to lean their manufacture 
so far that the Veblen good & Giffen good are becoming confused?

comments.text:

some similarities as well between, say, a Gold GTI and a Fabia vRS? Small 
blown engines, DSG transmissions - but can you feel a common DNA?

comments.text:

comments.text: How do you define character?

comments.text:
Regardless of the parts sharing or overlapping personalities, I think as 
long as they cater to a different markets, VW will be fine. Remember: a 
Rolls Ghost shares parts with a 760Li. But do owners care?
comments.author: Trades46

comments.text:
This kind of review. wayyy to nitpicking. People who buys car for prestige 
like me, simply doesnt care.
comments.author: Joe Foster

comments.text: OUR SAVER
comments.author: maron odeesh

comments.text:
Look at NEW Bentley Continental GT transmission and OLD 2002 Audi A4 
automatic transmission...do you see a difference?? :D
comments.author: Owan001

comments.text:
I think, while Chris does have a very good point, that the reason that some 
of the "driving switches and gear" is similar in position, is that that is 
the best place to put them - think about it, a big group such as VW has 
spend millions on figuring out how the best way to design a cabin is, isn't 
it going to use that knowledge so that its customers will feel best at home 
in their products because the switch-gear just "fits in"?
comments.author: Arch

comments.text:
Definitely a money machine. The biggest disappointment from my point of 
view is how Lamborghini got caught into it and the cheek they had to make a 
Gallardo which is essentially an R8. I think they should be completely 
different markets.
comments.author: sr20det6789

comments.text:
Excellent reportage. I was practically born in the back of an 'R' Type 
Bentley. But, would I buy one now if I had the means ? The answer is 
definitely 'NO'. I've lived in Germany for 30 years and have great respect 
for the engineering abilities of the Germans, but would I buy a car from 
here ? The answer is 'NO'. Because German cars are so characterless and 
cold.
comments.author: Stephen Lediard

comments.text:
Excellent review as always Chris. Love the Brit reviews . Keep up the great 
reviews. I have a 13 S4 and love it. Too bad the avant is not available 
here in Canada. We like our wagons.
comments.author: david dykeman

comments.text:
Your assumption is not true. I have driven all of them extensively. They do 
drive differently, but the differences are mostly because of setup. The 
similarities are bigger than the differences. All feel very well built and 
completely uninspiring to me.
comments.author: Bob van leeuwen

what is your problem with a wagon?! the whole wolrd loves them. or are you
